016package de.cuioss.test.jsf.junit5;
017
018import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.ApplicationConfigurator;
019import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.ComponentConfigurator;
020import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.JsfTestConfiguration;
021import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.RequestConfigurator;
022import de.cuioss.test.jsf.util.JsfEnvironmentHolder;
023import de.cuioss.test.valueobjects.util.IdentityResourceBundle;
024import jakarta.faces.context.FacesContext;
025import org.junit.jupiter.api.extension.ExtendWith;
026
027import java.lang.annotation.Documented;
028import java.lang.annotation.Repeatable;
029import java.lang.annotation.Retention;
030import java.lang.annotation.Target;
031
032import static java.lang.annotation.ElementType.TYPE;
033import static java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME;
034
035/**
036 * Using this annotations at type-level of a junit 5 test enable the
037 * myfaces-test-based test-framework for unit-tests. The configuration is
038 * implemented using some kind of decorator pattern (roughly). The actual
039 * configuration relies on two sources:
040 * <ul>
041 * <li>It scans for the annotations of type {@link JsfTestConfiguration}
042 * instantiates the corresponding classes and configures the environment
043 * accordingly</li>
044 * <li>It checks whether the actual test-class implements one of
045 * {@link ApplicationConfigurator}, {@link RequestConfigurator} or {@link ComponentConfigurator} and calls the
046 * corresponding methods accordingly, <em>after</em> the configurator derived by
047 * the annotations</li>
048 * </ul>
049 * <h3>Using</h3>
050 * <p>
051 * Simple Sample: Use a preconfigured JSF-context for the test providing
052 * BasicApplicationConfiguration
053 * </p>
054 *
055 * <pre>
056 * <code>
057 * &#64;EnableJsfEnvironment
058 * &#64;JsfTestConfiguration(BasicApplicationConfiguration.class)
059 * class JSFEnableTest {
060 * </code>
061 * </pre>
062 *
063 * <p>
064 * Complex Sample: Use a preconfigured JSF-context with access to the context
065 * information like {@link FacesContext}, {@link ComponentConfigurator}, ... as
066 * defined within {@link JsfEnvironmentHolder} With this setup you can
067 * programmatically access the element
068 * </p>
069 *
070 * <pre>
071 * <code>
072 * &#64;EnableJsfEnvironment
073 * &#64;JsfTestConfiguration(BasicApplicationConfiguration.class)
074 * class JsfSetupExtensionTest implements JsfEnvironmentConsumer {
075 *
076 * &#64;Setter
077 * &#64;Getter
078 * private JsfEnvironmentHolder environmentHolder;</code>
079 * </pre>
080 *
081 * <p>
082 * In addition there is a new way of dealing with localized messages for
083 * unit-tests. In essence there is the {@link IdentityResourceBundle}
084 * configured: This is helpful for tests where you want to ensure that a certain
085 * message key is used to create a message but do not want to test the actual
086 * ResourceBundle mechanism itself. It will always return the given key itself.
087 * As default this mechanism is active, you can change this by setting
088 * {@link #useIdentityResourceBundle()}. If it is active it is used as well for
089 * resolving the MessageBundle. In case of many annotations of
090 * {@link EnableJsfEnvironment} are in the type hierarchy, the one on the most
091 * concrete Type will be chosen, usually on the actual unit-test.
092 * </p>
093 *
094 * @author Oliver Wolff
095 */
096@Documented
097@Retention(RUNTIME)
098@Target(TYPE)
099@ExtendWith(JsfSetupExtension.class)
100@Repeatable(EnableJsfEnvironments.class)
101public @interface EnableJsfEnvironment {
102
103    /**
104     * @return boolean
105     */
106    boolean useIdentityResourceBundle() default true;
107
108}
